Thanks for trying this. There are some issues to be aware of for packaged actions as web actions via bindings. The lack of support isn’t a bug (it was intentional at the time). This has come up before so it’s worthwhile to try and enable this. 

1. If an action isn’t already a web action in the package, it can’t be accessed as a web action through the binding. That is a subject that binds the action can’t make it a web action (unless they already own it). So the creator/sharer of the package decides which of the actions to make available as web actions. Inherently this could create a dependence the subject can't control.

2. The entitlement check for a web action today is straightforward: namespace must own both and so implicitly entitled to them. With a binding you need to check if the binding continues to have rights to the bound package.

3. And of course you’ll need to add tests for the change/new feature.

I think this fix has moved a bit in the wrong direction. The mode @rabbah wants to keep is lazy evaluation of the Futures. While it is true, that all actions will be fetched at the same time, invocation will only wait for the first Future to complete before it starts invoking the sequence. The failing operation will be `invokeNextAction`. We can either attach `recoverWith` to the `invokeNextAction` call or even recover this within `invokeNextAction`. We can then use the current `accounting` object (since that's known when calling `invokeNextAction`) to apply the failure there. That should keep state up to that point (another thing mentioned by @rabbah) and should keep the change simple.

Thoughts?
Thanks @markusthoemmes. That's much simpler and preserves the pipelining between fetches and invokes.
@vvraskin I use the `local_action` and `run_once` options, I think it does the same thing

A more general finding: PR #3209 introduced a configurable limit for parameters in an activation. I guess it makes sense to use the same configuration settings for parameter size and activation parameter size. Can you please check how this could be done?

@dubee can give you more information on plans here.

### 1. Why need to write a new ActivationStoreProvider for `elasticsearch`?
Currently, `activations` are saved into `couchdb` using `ArtifactActivationStore`

couchdb has below disadvantage for saving activations
*  It is not convenience to  `delete big activations`(activation data is growing very fast on production env, when disk is full, need to delete, but should do compression at first, otherwise, disk usage will increase) 
* Couchdb's search feature is not stronger than `elasticsearch`.
* Maybe users has requirement to query user logs or activation in page, if we use `elasticsearch`, we can use `ELK`(elasticsearch, logstash, kibana) solution to give user power query function.
It seems `IBM cloud` also use `kibana` for `log` tab.

Since we provide `Provide an activation store SPI` in this patch, so i think it is necessary to implement a new ActivationStoreProvider  for `elasticsearch`

### 2.How to implement it?
* Implement this trait `ActivationStore`, for example:
```
class ElasticsearchActivationStore(actorSystem: ActorSystem, actorMaterializer: ActorMaterializer, logging: Logging) extends ActivationStore
```
* In class ElasticsearchActivationStore inner, we can use `https://github.com/sksamuel/elastic4s/` to implement it.

```
fatal: [172.17.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": ["docker", "run", "--rm", "-v", "/tmp:/tmp", "-u", "couchdb", "apache/couchdb:2.1", "sh", "-c", "echo rBA/m2eUwv7FML/UhasE2KdPoUkr6iahNx7x6UQt+6c= >> /tmp/erlang.cookie"], "delta": "0:00:01.200721", "end": "2018-07-20 18:20:30.445213", "msg": "non-zero return code", "rc": 2, "start": "2018-07-20 18:20:29.244492", "stderr": "sh: 1: cannot create /tmp/erlang.cookie: Permission denied", "stderr_lines": ["sh: 1: cannot create /tmp/erlang.cookie: Permission denied"], "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": []}
```

I think that the problem relates to the fact that `/tmp` is owned by root on macOS and the way how it is mounted in docker (not sure how it is exactly done there). I've tried to escalate the permissions with `become:true` for that task, but it failed as well prompting for sudo password. 

Is there a way to generate the cookie as a local action and then change the owner to couchdb?
Or should the cookie be always unique? What if we don't generate it each time when couchdb is deployed and use a static property instead?
@chetanmeh @markusthoemmes I think I have addressed all comments

great catch @tysonnorris . 
Indeed, as per the RFC https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.2 , _field names are case-insensitive_ , meaning `X-Request-ID`, or `x-request-id` should both work.

@markusthoemmes I added one more forgotten required change: enable ActionContainer based tests to explicitly use akka vs apache http client. While it is true that this could be accomplished by coercing test's akka config to include `akka-client: true`,  I think that until akka is the default client, tests should not be forced to run with multiple configs, but we still need to be able to force tests to run via a specific client (e.g. concurrency tests will fail on apache client, but not the akka client...).
For example forcing use of akka client will be done in container tests by changing: 
`withContainer(nodejsContainerImageName, env)(code)` to 
`withContainer(nodejsContainerImageName, env, true)(code)`
WDYT?
If the additional parameter doesn’t cause breaking downstream changes 👍 otherwise a separate method that tests can opt into.

@vvraskin thanks for the test
1. it's hard to find out the real uid of user couchdb on the host when docker enable the user namespace feature,  so I think the `become: true` is the right way, and it's normal for prompting for the sudo password, we can either use option `--ask-sudo-pass`, host var `ansible_sudo_pass` or enable the NOPASSWD for users on db hosts
 
2. I add an option for users to use their own value erlang cookie:
```
- name: "generate erlang cookie"
  local_action: command openssl rand -base64 32op
  register: random_stdout
  run_once: true
  when: erlang_cookie is not defined

- set_fact:
    erlang_cookie: "{{ random_stdout.stdout }}"
  when: erlang_cookie is not defined
``` 
we can pass an extra var `-e erlang_cookie=xxx`

> I thought in the same direction but then wondered if multiple identities for a namespace is in fact an edge-case of today' authentication rather than a common property of authentication, if that makes sense?

any organization that has a shared space is subject to this --- is that really an edge case?

> any organization that has a shared space is subject to this --- is that really an edge case?

A different authentication model might generate a token to access the namespace on the fly rather than providing the first key found in a list of keys allowed to a namespace.

Does that make sense?

> A different authentication model might generate a token to access the namespace on the fly rather than providing the first key found in a list of keys allowed to a namespace.

Hence the need to add a test - to enforce that if there is ambiguity there is an agreed resolution and the contract to the controller is the same.

Another way of restating: the standard authentication (couchdb) returns one of the identities where there are multiples, i.e., it is not an error. For all SPIs should the choice of error or return _an_ identity be consistent or left up to the implementation?

Yeah the client is changed by setting the additional param in downstream tests, and default value is false (use old client). It does mean that there needs to be 2 separate tests to run tests with both clients.

@tysonnorris the runtime tests now inherit properly from a common parent (the basic action runner tests) and that might provide a way for you to hide testing both old and new clients without requiring changes upstream... i didn't look too closely but mentioning it as it may be relevant.

I'm a bit unsure about a "per-test" flag here. I'd be okay to make the new akka-client the default for all those tests straight away (after a decent amount of local test runs to squash out obvious heisenbugs). No need to gradually enable them one after the other. WDYT?

Testing runtime repos, I ran into (so far) an issue with the proxy test in incubator-openwhisk-runtime-docker, where instead of receiving a `Timeout` we now (with akka client) receive `java.lang.IllegalStateException: The http server closed the connection unexpectedly before delivering responses for 1 outstanding requests`

So for docker "bad proxy" and "bad action" tests, to keep behavior parity, we need to change retry logic from:
```
case t: StreamTcpException if retry
```
to 
```
case t: RuntimeException if retry
``` 
because in some cases, akka http throws `UnexpectedConnectionClosureException`, which is private but extends `RuntimeException`. 
Some discussion is here: https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/768 in case you wonder about catching this specific exception...

Alternatively, we can update test cases for this edgy behavior handling?

Can update the test case - the scenario here is a bad proxy which doesn’t respond or even bring up an http endpoint. The invoker should properly terminate the container and destroy it and report and error (a la failed to start).

@rabbah In these failure scenarios the conductor action nows gets the control back and can decide what to do about the error instead of having the controller creating an activation record.

This is not always the case because there are other failure scenarios. In particular, the controller may fail to invoke the conductor action itself (internal failure or timeout). In general, with an at-most-once semantics there is no way to offer a total guarantee.

Summarizing a discussion with @rabbah: We agree that this is not optimal and might be subject to heuristics. It is however better what we have today and it serves as a catch-all around the invoker to catch any errors possible.
@markusthoemmes any other concerns here?

Our statsd integration with influx won't support tagging, but I think that we already have tagging option for Kamon introduced in this PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/commit/6f1a445f22f827bd91f75b01bc82988054febbc8
it would be useful to have an `elapsedTime` which is how much time is spent in the actual function. From this is it possible for one to determine what the "overhead" is.
That’s the “duration”. Yes there’s a small/epsilon difference vs measuring right around main. Have you observed a big deviation between that and duration?

I have, though to be fair what I have to do invoke a trigger with my transaction and wait for the result before my action can finish, so I can't really include that.

So, I delta is a combo cost of sending an event to a trigger plus that small epsilon.

In some cases it is very small, but in other cases it is 0.5 - 1.5 seconds
I don’t see how we measure elapsed time without including time to resolve the promise/asynchronous activity. Do you have a generic code snippet with timers added?
